messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-31T11:46:47Z
## Message ID: 20170831-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere possibly detected. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2017-08-31T06:56Z.

The activity is associated with the high speed stream starting at 2017-08-31.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2017-08-31T06:56:00-MPC-001.

## Notes 



NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 23, 2017 - August 29, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-30T21:30:07Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-08-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170830-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  No significant solar flares or CMEs were detected. Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME (starting on 2017-08-28T18:39Z), could have a glancing blow impact to missions near Earth around 2017-09-01T06:00Z (plus/minus 7 hours).  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.   The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-08-29T18:00Z-21:00Z.  This slight enhancement was associated with a coronating interaction region preceding a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-08-29.  

IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a CME (starting at 2017-08-18T13:48Z) around 2017-08-23T04:30Z.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)        
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-08-28T18:39Z     ~491            S                36/7                 19                          STEREO A, SOHO                  2017-08-29T01:07Z

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-08-18T13:48Z     ~496            S              -109/-9                21                          SOHO                            2017-08-18T21:09Z


## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-09-05T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be slow to moderate.  There a couple of active regions visible on the solar surface from the SDO and STEREO A imagery that have the potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections.   Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-08-31.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 16, 2017 - August 22, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-23T22:33:42Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-08-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170823-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare from active region 12672 (see list below) which also had numerous C and B class flares during this reporting period (together with active region 12671). In addition, there was 1 C-type CME originating from  active region 12671 (see details below).  

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=6 was reached during the synoptic period of 2017-08-22T00:00Z - 2017-08-22T03:00Z, which was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-08-17.  This high speed stream produced extended periods of Kp=3-5 between 2017-08-17 to 2017-08-21 with solar wind speeds reaching values of >700 km/s on 2017-08-20. The moderate enhancement of Kp=6 occurred when the coronal hole high speed stream was combined with an additional solar wind transient that reached Earth by the end of 2017-08-21.

PLASTIC/IMPACT instruments at STEREO A detected the CME arrival of an S-type CME (<500 km/s) around 2017-08-18T17:00Z.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-08-19T18:10Z. The fluxes remained elevated for several days crossing the threshold several times (see notifications 20170819-AL-001, 20170819-AL-002 and 20170821-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2017-08-20  01:36:00  02:30:00  01:52:00   M1.2   N05E90           

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 
 
Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-08-16T15:36Z     ~550            C               -61/11                25                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-08-29T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. The two active regions on the Earth-facing side of the solar disk can produce some flares or coronal mass ejection.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There is a small coronal hole near disk center that can produce some activity in the next 3-4 days.  

## Notes:  
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-22T14:45:20Z
## Message ID: 20170822-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-08-22T00:00Z to 2017-08-22T03:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-08-17T08:00Z, possibly with an embedded transient that started at 2017-08-21T21:33Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-08-22T00:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-21T19:33:33Z
## Message ID: 20170821-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with Activity ID 2017-08-19T18:10:00-RBE-001 (notification ID 20170819-AL-002). Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is currently around 176,000 pfu.  

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2017-08-17T08:00Z. 

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-08-21T17:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 09, 2017 - August 15, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-16T23:03:50Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-08-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170816-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  
A coronal hole high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-08-11.  Solar wind speeds reached values of >600 km/s on 2017-08-12.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was enhanced at the beginning of the reporting period due to a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2017-08-04, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period (see notification 0170809-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

None Observed

None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-08-22T23:59Z

The solar is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming reporting period.   There are a few active regions on the solar surface that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around the next several days.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 02, 2017 - August 08, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-09T22:15:00Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-02T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-08-08T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170809-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period, with no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream starting around 2017-08-08 for which solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-08-05T19:00Z. The fluxes remained elevated for several days crossing the threshold several times (see notifications 20170805-AL-002 and 20170807-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-08-04.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-08-15T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Active region 12670 (currently to the SW of disk center) had large eruptions in the past few weeks, but it has been quiescent since it rotated on the Earth's facing solar disk.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  A small coronal hole is also visible on the Earth-facing side of the solar disk, which will produce a high speed stream in several days.

R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-09T19:51:54Z
## Message ID: 20170809-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID 2017-08-05T19:00:00-RBE-001 (notifications ID 20170805-AL-001, ID 20170805-AL-002, and ID 20170807-AL-001). Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is currently around 80,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-08-04T07:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-08-05T19:00:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 26, 2017 - August 01, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-08-02T23:35:02Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-07-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-08-01T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170802-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data detected a CME arrival around 2017-07-30T02:00Z.  This signature may be associated with the CME starting on 2017-07-28T05:36Z (see notification 20170728-AL-002).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, this CME was also estimated to impact Spitzer at 2017-07-31T16:21Z and Mars (glancing blow) at 2017-08-03T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-07-24T15:05Z.  The fluxes remained elevated several days crossing the threshold several times (see notifications 20170726-AL-001 and 20170728-AL-001).  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-07-20.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-07-28T05:36Z     ~574            C              -136/4                 38                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-08-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-08-08T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate.  The recently numbered active region 12670 located around S05E70 has potential of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.   Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-08-03.
